question: Are campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts open?
answer:
Lodging facilities â hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short-term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities, RV parks, seasonal resorts and marinas â may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents, those who have met the quarantine requirement, and essential workers.
Find details and up-to-date information on lodging, campgrounds and other accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD) ) and find information about traveling to Vermont from the Health Department.
All guests must complete a health questionnaire upon check-in and must provide a Vermont driverâs license or signed document certifying that they met the quarantine and travel requirements. Out-of-state guests are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert â a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19 â for daily reminders from the Vermont Department of Health.
If an individual has concerns about lodging facilities that are violating the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order, the Department of Public Safety has created an online non-compliance complaint form to gather more information.

question: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
answer:
Starting June 19, facilities may offer limited visitation outside with residents. Check with the facility first before planning a visit.
Medically necessary personnel and visitors for residents receiving end-of-life care are allowed inside. Read the executive order.
The Health Department recommends that all health care personnel in long-term care facilities and other congregate settings where health care is provided wear face masks, regardless of the presence of COVID-19 in the facility.
Any new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.
Senior Centers may reopen with guidance from the Health Department and the Department of Aging and Independent Living. Adult Day programs remain closed.
There is guidance Â­on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of senior living communities, which includes making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents/staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.
Find more guidance and information for long-term care and group living settings.

question: What should businesses and non-profits do?
answer:
Vermont is starting a phased approach to reopen the economy, balancing overall social and economic wellbeing with preventing a rise in COVID-19 that would set us back. Businesses deemed âessentialâ may continue to operate under pre-existing
guidance, with the addition of the mandatory health and safety
requirements.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has the resources businesses need on their COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:


A step-by-step reopening guide for businesses


Up-to-date sector-specific guidance


Mandatory health and safety requirements. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others. Businesses and non-profits may require customers or clients to wear masks.


Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses


Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses from the Health Department.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: Are outpatient services open?
answer:
Outpatient services are reopened for professions licensed by the Office of Professional Regulation.
Those professions that provide care without physical contact or with some physical contact Â may resume outpatient services â such as licensed alcohol and drug counselors (LADACs), Allied Mental Health, dieticians, psychologists, social workers, acupuncturists, chiropractors, physical therapists, occupational therapists, opticians and optometrists.
For those professions involved in care that is more likely to expose them to the COVID-19 virus â such as doctors of osteopathy, naturopathy, physician assistants, and nurses â outpatient clinic visits and diagnostic imaging may resume.

question: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
answer:
The challenge with dentistry is the generation of aerosols as part of many office-based activities. This includes dental hygiene through a variety of preventive, restorative, endodontic, periodontic and orthodontic procedures.
Dentists can now resume all procedures, including those that generate aerosol.Â Read the Interim Guidance for Resuming Dental Services in Vermont.
The dental community is confident it has the existing knowledge, skills, office processes and equipment, testing protocols, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to accomplish these safely. They will share the efforts and practices they have adopted with their patients.
Health care professionals must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.
Find more information for health care professionals.

question: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answer:
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested. Talk to your health care provider to find out where to get tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1.Â For travelers who are completing quarantine in their home state, your home state may offer testing for people without symptoms.
You can end your quarantine period before 14 days only if:

You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period;
You are tested on Day 7 or later;
You remain in quarantine until the result comes back; AND
You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms.

For anyone coming into Vermont, Day 1 is the day after you arrive in Vermont.
However, if you end your quarantine period before 14 days, you must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days. If you develop symptoms at any point during your quarantine, contact your health care provider and the Health Department right away. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1. Sign up to receive daily symptom check reminders.
For close contacts of people who have tested positive:

If you are NOT able to completely physically separate yourself from the person who tested positive â for example, you live in the same home â Day 1 of your quarantine is the day after they have ended their self-isolation.
If you are able to completely physically separate from the person who tested positive â for example you do not live in the same home â Day 1 of your quarantine is the day after the last time you were in close contact with them.

Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine.
New admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

question: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
answer:
Lodging operations, short-term rentals, campgrounds and marinas may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents, those who have met the quarantine requirement, and essential workers under mandatory health and safety requirements.
Lodging operators should recommend that all out-of-state guests sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. Guests from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine. They have the option to quarantine at a lodging facility for 14 days if they make stops along the way or travel by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.
Find details on the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

Up-to-date guidance for lodging and accommodations and for campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses from the Health Department.
The Vermont State Police and local law enforcement will monitor lodging providers for compliance and work with the Attorney Generalâs Office on additional compliance measures if needed. Learn about guidance on enforcement of the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order from the Vermont Department of Public Safety.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: What should schools, child care and summer programs in Vermont do?
answer:
Schools will reopen in the fall for in-person instruction. The Agency of Education and the Health Department created aÂ guidance document for school administrators and personnel as they plan and implement the reopening of schools for the 2020-21 school year. Read A Strong and Healthy Start: Safety and Health Guidance for Reopening Schools, Fall 2020.
Child care providers can decide to reopen if they follow health and safety precautions. Some may choose not to reopen or are unable to do so. Find guidance on child care from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development as it becomes available.
Child care programs remain open for Essential Persons, which are defined as including:

staff and providers of child care and education services (including custodial and kitchen staff and other support staff) for children of other Essential Persons
providers of healthcare
criminal justice personnel
public health employees
firefighters
Vermont National Guard personnel called to duty for this response
other first responders
state employees determined to be essential for response to this crisis under the State Emergency Operations Center.

Guidance and Resources for Child Care and Summer Programs

Health Guidance for Childcare Programs and Summer Programs that are or will open during the COVID-19 pandemic
Health & Safety Guidance for Childcare & Summer Programs FAQ
Sample Daily COVID-19 Health Checklist Child Care and School Age Camps/Care
Sample Weekly COVID-19 Health Checklist Child Care and School Age Camps/Care

Find more resources and information for schools, child care and summer programs.

question: Do I need to quarantine if out-of-state visitors are staying in my home?
answer:
If you are hosting travelers under quarantine in your home or lodging, you do not also need to quarantine. If you are sharing space, stay at least 6 feet from the people under quarantine. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces. Disinfect commonly touched surfaces and check for symptoms for 14 days.
Visitors from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. Read the travel guidance and check the map of approved counties, which is updated weekly.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for information for travelers to Vermont. They can get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: What should returning and new college students do?
answer:
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
All students are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.
Students from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. Read the travel guidance and check the map of approved counties, which is updated weekly.
College students returning to Burlington can also use the cityâs Supportive Quarantine Pilot Program. The program includes a move-in care package of fresh local goods, a mask, and hygiene supplies.

question: What do employers need to do to reopen their business?
answer:
All businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements as they reopen.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has the resources businesses need on their COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses, including a step-by-step reopening guide for businesses and sector-specific guidance.
Stagnant water in plumbing systems can lead to illness or cause disease. As offices, retail businesses, gyms and other buildings begin to reopen, they should follow state guidance and recommendations before using the drinking water again. Read the CDCâs Guidance for Reopening Buildings After Prolonged Shutdown or Reduced Operation for more information.

question: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
answer:
Isolation is for people who are sick with COVID-19.
Quarantine is for people with no symptoms who are returning to Vermont from out of state or who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19. This helps prevent spread of disease before a person knows they are sick or if they are infected with the virus without feeling symptoms.
Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days before doing any activities outside of the home, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms. Sign up forÂ daily symptom check reminders.
Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19.
For more information, see the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart.
See the latest quarantine guidance for people visiting or returning to Vermont.

question: Are there any translated materials about COVID-19?
answer:
There is information about COVID-19 available in several languages from NewAmericansInVermont.com.
Find more information and translated materials from the Health Department.

question: What should I do if I need to see a dentist?
answer:
Dentists can now perform all dental procedures again, including those that generate aerosol. The dental community is confident it has the necessary knowledge, skills, office processes and equipment, testing protocols, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to safely provide care.
Contact your dentist to find out if you can be seen. If you donât have a regular dentist and need help finding one, call 211.
Do not delay care if you have:

Heavy bleeding that wonât stop
Painful swelling in or around your mouth
Pain in a tooth, teeth or jawbone
Gum infection with pain or swelling
Treatment after surgery (dressing change, stitch removal)
Broken or knocked out tooth
Denture adjustment for people receiving radiation or other treatment for cancer
Wire of braces poking your cheek or gums
Biopsy of abnormal tissue

question: Can I be tested for COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for referral to a test site.
Currently, any person without symptoms who lives or works in Vermont can be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration for testing is required.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
There is no cost to individuals for the COVID-19 test.
Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild. If an asymptomatic patient who is currently in quarantine would like to end their quarantine period early based upon a negative test result, health care providers should refer them to a pop-up testing site on Day 7 or later of their quarantine.
The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.
The State began expanding testing in late April. We know that with increased testing we are likely to see a rise in positive cases, and we are prepared to handle such a scenario. A new Testing and Tracing Task Force has been created to guide and oversee this process.

question: Is there food available if I need it?
answer:
The Vermont Foodbank is partnering with The Abbey Group, the State of Vermont, and the Vermont National Guard to provide boxes of chicken, produce, dairy products, and non-perishable food at distributions held throughout the state. Distributions will require pre-registration to reduce wait times and improve the experience for people picking up food.
Register for food distribution. For more questions or for people who do not have internet access and would like to register, please call 2-1-1.
People who are sick, have been asked to quarantine, or donât have transportation can send a friend or relative to pick up meals for them. Those picking up food can come to the location nearest to them, open their trunk, and the food will be loaded by members of the Vermont National Guard.
Visit the Vermont Foodbank for more details on food resources during COVID-19.

question: What is Sara Alert?
answer:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. People who have tested positive for COVID-19, their close contacts, and people traveling or returning to Vermont can quickly and easily sign up for to receive free daily reminders to check themselves for symptoms by email, text or phone call. If symptoms are reported, the Health Department will reach out to provide guidance and next steps. Sara Alert helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.
Please note, Sara Alert is not a contact tracing system. It is not GPS based, so it does not monitor your movements.
If you are traveling or returning to Vermont, you are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.
Sign up for Sara Alert.

question: Are summer camps and residential summer college programs happening?
answer:
Summer day camps serving Vermonters and those meeting the 14-day quarantine requirements, overnight summer camps, and limited residential summer college programs may operate under the Health Guidance for Childcare Programs and Summer Programs.
Find information on the mandatory health and safety requirements for overnight camps and residential summer college programs, including quarantine requirements for out-of-state staff and campers, guidance for families dropping off campers, and wearing cloth face masks or coverings around other people, from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
Find more information about what parents can expect from child care and school age camps and care from the Vermont Department of Health.

question: Are bars and restaurants open?
answer:
Restaurants may offer outdoor dining service under certain conditions. Bars, breweries, distilleries, cideries, and tasting rooms may also offer outdoor dining and beverage service under certain health and safety requirements.
Limited indoor dining at restaurants and bars is allowed.
Establishments can continue to offer food takeout and delivery.
Find more details and up-to-date information about bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

question: Can I get COVID-19 from swimming in a lake or river?
answer:
The COVID-19 virus could possibly enter waterways through untreated wastewater that is discharged into waterways following large rain events or for other reasons. The virus has been found in untreated wastewater, but there has been no evidence that a person can get COVID-19 from being exposed to untreated wastewater or sewerage systems.
According to the CDC, it is thought that the COVID-19 virus does not spread through standard municipal and individual septic system wastewater treatment practices. Guidance will be updated if anything new is learned.
The Health Department recommends that towns do routine weekly E. coli testing and after large storm events during the swim season. These tests are a good indication of the water quality, meaning that if the E. coli levels are low, then COVID-19 virus levels are also expected to be low.
The best practices for staying healthy while swimming are to obey signage at beaches, do not swim during and following large rain events, and do not swallow the water.

question: What is the Health Department doing?
answer:
The Vermont Department of Health is working closely with long-term care facilities and other group living facilities to prepare for COVID-19 cases and prevent outbreaks, by reviewing CDC guidance for infection control and supporting development of strategies and plans. If cases occur in these settings, the Vermont Department of Health helps the facility implement control measures and prevent additional cases.
The Department does contact tracing to investigate possible travel or exposure history and to identify anyone who had close contact with the person who has tested positive for COVID-19. Those individuals will be assessed for their exposure risk and provided with guidance for their health. Where appropriate, they will receive recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.
Find up-to-date information on the Health Department's COVID-19 website.

question: How should we practice social distancing with children?
answer:
Social distancingÂ means keeping at least 6 feet awayÂ from othersÂ and avoidingÂ placesÂ whereÂ you may beÂ close toÂ otherÂ people.
Choose other trusted households to socialize with that are also taking health and safety precautions, such as family, neighbors or friends. A trusted household is one that has taken seriously the importance of social distancing and proper hygiene in their day-to-day lives. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Choose outdoor activities where itâs easy to maintain a 6-foot distance. Remember that ticks are active this time of year. Learn how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.
Continue to take advantage of technology toÂ play games orÂ keep in touch with friends and family who you are not meeting up with in person.Â These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.
Most people who get sick from COVID-19 â including children â will experience mild symptoms and recover,Â but following the general precautions of wearing a cloth face mask or covering, keeping aÂ 6-foot distance from others, washing hands often, and staying home if you are sick will help usÂ limit the virusâs spread to ourÂ vulnerable populations.
Find more resources for families with children.

question: Can I use reusable grocery bags?
answer:
Yes, people can continue to use reusable grocery bags. However, some stores are choosing to no longer allow reusable bags and containers at this time. Check with your local store for their current policies.
After July 1, stores and food service establishments will no longer provide plastic bags at check-out. Youâll have the option to purchase paper bags for 10 cents each or use reusable bags. If a store has temporarily banned reusable bags, consider putting your groceries back into your cart and bag them at your car. Some stores and food establishments may still offer plastic bags after July 1 since they are allowed to use the ones they currently have in stock until they are gone.
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. It is important to remember to wash your hands before you eat and to avoid touching your face.
Make sure you clean your reusable bags regularly, which can also help prevent illnesses from bacteria, such as E.coli, that are from meat and unwashed fruits and vegetables.
Find more information and tips about the single-use plastics ban from the Department of Environmental Conservation.

question: What is known about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19?
answer:
According to the CDC, Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs. We do not yet know what causes MIS-C. However, we know that many children with MIS-C had the COVID-19 virus, or had been around someone with COVID-19. MIS-C can be serious, even deadly, but most children who were diagnosed with this condition have gotten better with medical care.
MIS-C is rare, and it remains unknown whether multisystem inflammatory syndrome only occurs in children or if it also can occur in adults.
Learn more about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Health.

question: What can I wear if my health or work environment doesn't allow me to wear a cloth face mask or covering?
answer: People who have trouble breathing can wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom or a face shield. Face shields are generally not recommended because they are more for health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in. However, if your work environment or health does not allow you to wear a cloth face mask, wearing a face shield is better than having no barrier on your nose and mouth.

question: Can pets get sick from COVID-19?
answer:
We are still learning about the virus that causes COVID-19, but it appears that it can spread from people to animals in some situations.
There have been a few confirmed cases of animals infected with COVID-19:

a tiger at a zoo in New York
two pet cats in New York
a cat in Minnesota
aÂ dog in New York

The CDC recommends the following:
Until we learn more about how this virus affects animals, treat pets as you would other human family members to protect them from a possible infection.
Because there is a small risk that people with COVID-19 could spread the virus to animals, CDC recommends that pet owners limit their petâs interaction with people outside their household.

Keep cats indoors when possible and do not let them roam freely outside.
Walk dogs on a leash at least 6 feet away from others.
Avoid public places where large numbers of people gather.
Do not put face coverings on pets. Covering a petâs face could harm them.

Talk to your veterinarian if your pet gets sick or if you have any concerns about your petâs health.
Learn more about what to do if you have pets and answers to frequently asked questions about COVID-19 and animals from the CDC.
Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

question: What does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean for Vermonters?
answer:
Under the Governorâs executive order extension â Be Smart, Stay Safe â Vermonters are encouraged to limit their exposure to the COVID-19 virus outside their homes as much as possible.
Vermonters should travel only as needed:

For personal safety, medical care and care of others
For work, although all workers should continue to work remotely whenever possible
For shopping and services available at all businesses and non-profit and government entities determined to be critical and those which have been authorized to resume operations
To get fresh air and exercise by taking advantage of outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities that require low or no direct physical contact
For limited social interactions and gatherings of 25 or fewer, preferably in outdoor settings
For in-state stays at available lodging, campground and marina facilities

Vermonters should follow health and safety precautions to help keep the virus from spreading by:

Staying home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.
Keeping a physical distance of at least 6 feet away from others (except for those you live with).
Washing or sanitizing your hands often.
Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain (for example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path).
Coughing and sneezing into your elbow (even when wearing a face covering).
Limiting travel to within Vermont to the extent possible and when you do travel, limit non-essential stops.

Older adults (age 65 and over), and people with underlying medical conditions, like heart and lung disease or diabetes, are more likely to develop severe illness. They should take extra precautions.
Learn how to safely connect with friends and family. These recommended practices will help you weigh the risk and plan accordingly.
Read the latest updates to the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development has resources for individuals and sector-specific guidance for details on which businesses are open.

question: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
answer:
Vermonters are allowed to gather in groups of 25 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Choose other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Vermonters may hold yard sales and garage sales with 25 or fewer people. Hosts and visitors must keep a distance of at least 6 feet from others, and it is recommended that they wear cloth face masks or coverings.
Gatherings of more than 25 people are still prohibited. This includes weddings, graduation ceremonies, and other social gatherings.
All traditional fairs and festivals have been canceled until further notice.
Organized outdoor markets, like flea markets, must follow the farmers market guidance from the Agency of Agriculture, Food & Markets (AAFM).
Farmers markets and pick-your-own farms and orchards must follow best practices outlined by AAFM.
Find more information on the health and safety requirements for sectors that are open from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
If leaving the home, Vermonters should adhere to social distancing policies, including remaining 6 feet from others (except for those with whom they share a home), wearing a cloth face mask or covering, and thoroughly and regularly washing hands.

question: Do family members of people who traveled internationally or by cruise ship need to stay at home?
answer:
If your family member has traveled internationally to any country or traveled by cruise ship or river cruise voyage, they should quarantine for 14 days, and the other household members should do self-observation for 14 days.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
Find more information from the CDC about returning from international travel and returning from cruise ship and river cruise voyages.
Stay up to date on the latest COVID-19 travel advisories from the CDC.

question: What do I do if I'm a close contact of someone who is waiting for their test results?
answer:
People can be contagious for up to 48 hours before showing symptoms, so you should quarantine for 48 hours or until the test results come back.
If the test results come back positive (the person has COVID-19), then you should continue to quarantine for 14 days. Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
If the test results come back negative (the person does not have COVID-19), then you should start self-observation.
Read the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart for details.

question: Can I get tested with a swab in the front of my nose?
answer:
There is a test available that uses a dry swab to collect a sample from the front of your nose. At this time, the supplies needed for this type of test are limited. This type of test is being prioritized for different groups of people who may not be able to tolerate the longer nose swab (nasopharyngeal or NP) that collects samples from the back of the nose and throat. This includes children, patients at risk of increased bleeding or complications, patients with nasal irregularities (for example, polyps, deviated septum), people who need regular and repeated testing (for example, employees or residents of skilled nursing facilities), and those without the cognitive ability to understand the testing procedure.
Your health care provider will determine if you should be referred for this type of test. Please note the pop-up testing sites use the longer NP swabs.

question: What should I do if I have traveled internationally or traveled by cruise ship?
answer:
If youâve returned from international travel or from a cruise ship or river cruise voyage, you should for quarantine for 14 days.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
Find more information from the CDC about returning from international travel and returning from cruise ship and river cruise voyages.
If you develop symptoms of COVID-19, contact your health care provider right away.
Stay up to date on the latest COVID-19 travel advisories from the CDC.

question: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
answer:
Cases of COVID-19 have been reported in all states, and some areas are experiencing community spread of the disease. Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19.
The CDC recommends you limit travel as much as possible, especially if your trip is not essential, and practice social distancing especially if you are at higher risk of severe illness. Donât travel if you are sick or travel with someone who is sick.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
answer:
If you are visiting or returning to Vermont you may need to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. You are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
If you are coming from certain counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections, you do not need to quarantine. Read the travel guidance and check the map of approved counties, which is updated weekly.
All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle and making no stops along the way OR
Quarantine at a lodging facility or Vermont home for 14 days if you are making stops along the way or traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

You have the option to get tested on Day 7 of your quarantine. Learn more under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: Do I need to quarantine if I do a short trip (day trip)?
answer: People who regularly commute to or from Vermont do not need to quarantine.Â In addition, people who live near a border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state may make day trips to that state for essential work, health care, and other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody without quarantining. For anyone else making a day trip to or from Vermont, read the cross-state travel guidance from theÂ Agency of Commerce and Community Development.

question: I am traveling to Vermont. Do I need to quarantine if I donât make any stops along the way?
answer:
You do not need to quarantine if you are traveling in your personal vehicle from an approved county in New York and New England, and do not make any stops along the way. Be sure to fill up your gas tank and pack food, water and other essentials before you leave.
Visitors and travelers coming to Vermont by plane, bus or train â or those who make stops in a personal vehicle â must quarantine for 14 days.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
All visitors and travelers coming to Vermont are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.

question: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
answer:
If you are returning to your second or seasonal home in Vermont, you may be required to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. You are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
If you are coming from certain counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections, you do not need to quarantine. Read the travel guidance and check the map of approved counties, which is updated weekly.
All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle and making no stops along the way OR
Quarantine at a lodging facility or Vermont home for 14 days if you are making stops along the way or traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

You have the option to get tested on Day 7 of your quarantine. Learn more under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: Where can I get tested for COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider for a referral. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for a referral to a test site. If you are having a medical emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to the hospital.
Find out what to do if you are sick from the CDC and what to do while youâre waiting for test results.
Pop-up Testing Sites and Pharmacy Testing Locations
Any person without symptoms who lives or works in Vermont can be tested at no cost at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. This includes people who live in a neighboring state and work in Vermont, second homeowners, and college students. Children under 12 months cannot be tested at a pop-up testing site. Please talk to your childâs doctor about testing options. Registration for testing is required. For people who do not have internet access and want to register at a pop-up site, they can call 2-1-1 for help with registration.
Some pharmacies may offer testing at no cost for people without symptoms. Call the pharmacy first to see if testing is offered and to schedule an appointment.
Register for a pop-up testing site.
For pop-up testing site registration questions and issues, call 802-828-2828. If you need transportation to a pop-up testing site, please call 833-387-7200 at least two days before your scheduled appointment.
The test is a nasopharyngeal swab, or NP swab, where a health care professional uses a swab to collect a sample from the back of the nose and throat. This test will tell you if you have a current infection. It is not a serology/antibody test, which means it will not tell you if you were infected in the past.
Find answers to more frequently asked questions about pop-up testing sites.
Some commercial businesses may offer other testing opportunities. You can contact them directly for more information.

question: Why is Vermont testing people who do not have symptoms of COVID-19?
answer:
The CDC issued a recommendation that testing should be occurring at a particular rate per 100,000 people. This is so we can see if the case numbers start to grow again as the state reopens. In Vermont, to achieve that rate, we need to test about 1,000 people per day.
As we test more and more people without symptoms, we are finding fewer and fewer cases. Early on, we only tested people who were very, very ill. Even then, a vast majority did not have COVID-19. Over time we started to test people who were moderately ill, then with mild symptoms, and now we also can include people who do not have symptoms.
Testing helps us better understand the current rate of active infections of COVID-19 in Vermont, and helps to contain and slow the spread to others. It also lets us see how that rate is changing over time as we slowly reopen the state.

question: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
answer:
Justices of the peace and other officiants may perform in-person marriages if there are 25 or fewer people. Town offices may decide to issue marriage licenses.
Ceremonies should preferably be outside, while keeping a 6-foot distance from others, and wearing cloth face masks or coverings.
If you are visiting Vermont you may need to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
Find up-to-date information on marriage ceremonies from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development

question: Should I be tested for COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic for referral to a test site.
Any person without symptoms who lives or works in Vermont can be tested at a pop-up testing site without a doctorâs referral. Registration for testing is required.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.

question: What should businesses do to protect workers and customers?
answer:
Current information is on the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

Up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others. Businesses may require customers to wear cloth face masks or coverings.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

More resources are available from the Health Department:

COVID-19 Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses
Health resources for businesses and food and lodging businesses
COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and Best Practices for Retail Food Stores, Restaurants, and Food Pick-Up/Delivery Services During the COVID-19 Pandemic from the FDA.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
answer:
According to the CDC, some people might be at higher risk of getting very sick from COVID-19, including older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions like heart disease, diabetes, lung disease or moderate to severe asthma, severe obesity, chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis, liver disease, or people who are immunocompromised including cancer treatment. People who live in a nursing home or long-term care facility are also at high risk of getting very sick from COVID-19.
In addition to the general COVID-19 prevention steps, older adults and people with underlying medical conditions should take extra precautions including:

Stay close to home as much as possible. Traveling out of state is not recommended since the virus is still widespread in neighboring states and across the country.
Be aware of your surroundings. Choose outdoor settings over indoor settings. Pay attention to the size of the space, crowding, the number of people there, and if they are wearing face coverings and keeping a 6-foot distance.
Choose activities that donât require close contact. Minimize close contact while talking or doing anything that requires exertion, shouting or singing.
Keep your social circle small. Choose a few other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions.
Continue your medications and do not change your treatment plan without talking to your health care provider.
Have at least a two-week supply of prescription and non-prescription medications.Â Consider having your medications delivered.
Talk to your health care provider about whether your vaccinations are up to date.
Do not delay getting emergency care for your underlying medical condition because of COVID-19.
Call your health care provider if you have any concerns about your underlying medical conditions or if you get sick and think that you may have COVID-19.

Read the CDCâs full guidance on people who are at higher risk for serious illness from COVID-19.

question: Is the state reopened?
answer:
Vermont has begun a phased approach to reopen the economy, balancing overall social and economic wellbeing with preventing a rise in COVID-19 that would set us back.
Current information for businesses, non-profit and government operations that are open and their health and safety requirements under the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order is available from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
Businesses can find a step-by-step guide to reopening and up-to-date sector-specific guidance from the ACCD.
Find the most recent Governorâs Executive Orders for more information.

question: How long is the turnaround for testing?
answer:
Test results will be available typically within 1 â 3 days. You will get your test results from your health care provider. However, if you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
If you got tested at a pop-up testing site, you will get a letter with your test results within a week. If you have a positive result, a Public Health Nurse will call you within a few days.
Find out what to do while you're waiting for test results. Contact your health care provider with any questions.
The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
answer:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. Symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus. Not everyone infected with the COVID-19 virus has symptoms. People with these symptoms may have COVID-19:

Fever (100.4 Â°F or greater) or chills
Cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Headache
New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting
Diarrhea

This list does not include all possible symptoms. The CDC will continue to update the list of symptoms as more is learned. You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.
Call your health care provider if you are having symptoms. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic.
Learn more about COVID-19.

question: I’ve heard that home remedies can cure or prevent the virus.
answer:
There’s no evidence from the outbreak that eating garlic, sipping water every 15 minutes or taking vitamin C will protect people from the new coronavirus. Same goes for using essential oils, colloidal silver and steroids.
Some posts have suggested that putting sesame oil on your body or spraying yourself with alcohol or chlorine will kill the virus. That’s also false.

question: Can coronavirus travel by wind? Is it safe to go for a walk or exercise outside if someone jogs or bikes past me?
answer:
Coronavirus cannot travel very far in the air, the World Health Organization says.
The virus is mainly spread through small droplets from an infected person’s nose or mouth, which get released when a person coughs, sneezes or speaks. 
These droplets “are relatively heavy, do not travel far and quickly sink to the ground,” the WHO said. 
While the wind isn’t a big risk factor, contaminated surfaces are. Those respiratory droplets can land on surfaces such as tables, doorknobs and handrails — and subsequently infect others who touch those surfaces and later touch their eyes, nose or mouth. 
That’s why wearing a face mask won’t necessarily protect you from coronavirus. The primary benefit of wearing a mask is to protect others if you’re sick or an asymptomatic carrier of the virus.

question: Should I stop wearing contacts and switch to glasses? Would that help reduce my risk of infection?
answer:
“There is no evidence to suggest contact lens wearers are more at risk for acquiring COVID-19 than eyeglass wearers,” the CDC says.
“However, wearing contact lenses can increase your chance of getting an eye infection — especially if you do not care for them the right way.”
It’s important for contact wearers to wash their hands the right way and disinfect the lenses.

question: Can students expect to go back to school anytime in 2020?
answer:
It’s too early to say for sure, but CDC Director Dr. Robert Redfield warned that a second wave of coronavirus later this year could be even more difficult because it could coincide with the flu season.
As for the rest of the current school year, at least 43 states have ordered or recommended that schools remain closed. 
And some universities say it’s possible in-person classes might be canceled until 2021. 
Around the world, 1.6 billion children have been affected by school closures, according to UNESCO. But some schools have already reopened – with new precautions. In Denmark, students sit 6 feet apart from each other, enter school at staggered times, and spend more time outdoors.

question: Can you safely reuse a non-cloth mask that you can’t wash, like a disposable mask?
answer:
Yes you can, said Dr. Joseph Vinetz, an infectious diseases professor at Yale School of Medicine. 
To disinfect masks that you can’t wash, Vinetz recommends leaving them in a clean, safe place in your home for a few days. After that, it should no longer be infectious, as this coronavirus is known to survive on hard surfaces for only up to three days. 
You can reuse cloth masks, too. Just launder them between each use on a high-heat setting. 
Learn more about which masks you shouldn’t buy and how you can make your own (without having to sew) here.

question: What’s so different about coronavirus that we have to shut down businesses? Why practice social distancing now, when we didn’t during the SARS and swine flu epidemics?
answer:
Unlike SARS and swine flu, the novel coronavirus is both highly contagious and especially deadly, CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. 
“SARS was also a coronavirus, and it was a new virus at the time,” Gupta said. “In the end, we know that SARS ended up infecting 8,000 people around the world and causing around 800 deaths. So very high fatality rate, but it didn’t turn out to be very contagious.”
The swine flu, or H1N1, “was very contagious and infected some 60 million people in the United States alone within a year,” Gupta said. “But it was far less lethal than the flu even — like 1/3 as lethal as the flu.” 
What makes the novel coronavirus different is that “this is both very contagious … and it appears to be far more lethal than the flu as well,” Gupta said. “So both those things, in combination I think, are why we’re taking this so seriously.”

question: This isolation is taking a toll on my mental health. And I’m starting to feel depressed and anxious about the pandemic. How can I get help?
answer:
The Crisis Text Line is available texting to 741741. Trained volunteers and crisis counselors are staffed 24/7, and the service is free. 
The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration Disaster Distress Helpline provides 24/7, 365-day-a-year crisis counseling and support to people experiencing emotional distress related to disasters. Call 1-800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746 to connect with a trained crisis counselor.
For health care professionals and essential workers, For the Frontlines offers free 24/7 crisis counseling and support for workers dealing with stress, anxiety, fear or isolation related to coronavirus. 
For more resources, check out CNN’s guide to giving and getting help during the pandemic.

question: Will ingesting or injecting disinfectants, like the ones that kill viruses on surfaces, protect me against coronavirus or kill coronavirus if I already have it?
answer:
“That’s a bad idea,” said Dr. Colleen Kraft, an infectious diseases professor at Emory University School of Medicine. “It could definitely kill you.” 
President Donald Trump wondered aloud during a press conference whether there’s “a way we can do something like that, by injection inside or almost a cleaning.”
But the Reckitt Benckiser Group, which produces Lysol cleaning products, said “under no circumstance” should disinfectants be put into the human body.

question: Can mosquitoes transmit coronavirus?
answer:
No. “To date there has been no information nor evidence to suggest that the new coronavirus could be transmitted by mosquitoes,” the World Health Organization says. 
“The new coronavirus is a respiratory virus which spreads primarily through droplets generated when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or through droplets of saliva or discharge from the nose.”

question: Is it true young people with coronavirus are also having blood clots and strokes?
answer:
Yes, some young adults have suffered strokes after getting coronavirus. 
“The virus seems to be causing increased clotting in the large arteries, leading to severe stroke,” said Dr. Thomas Oxley, a neurosurgeon at Mount Sinai Health System in New York.
“Our report shows a seven-fold increase in incidence of sudden stroke in young patients during the past two weeks,” he said. “Most of these patients have no past medical history and were at home with either mild symptoms (or in two cases, no symptoms) of Covid.”
At least one patient has died, and others are in rehabilitation facilities, intensive care or in the stroke unit, Oxley said. Only one patient went home, but will require intense care.

question: What can we learn from how other countries handled coronavirus?
answer:
Singapore was initially praised for its clampdown on the virus. Even people who had no symptoms but tested positive had to be hospitalized until they tested negative. 
But Singapore was also relaxed, allowing businesses, churches, restaurants and schools to stay open during its first wave of the virus. And some communities were overlooked by government testing.
The number of cases in Singapore shot up, and the country suffered a strong second wave of coronavirus. 
By contrast, Germany, South Korea, Iceland and Taiwan have been able to suppress the virus. They also have among the lowest death rates from Covid-19 in the world. 
Taiwan was proactive, launching its Central Epidemic Command Center before the island even confirmed its first infection. 
Iceland required all its citizens returning to the country to undergo 14 days of quarantine – regardless of which country they traveled from.
Germany and South Korea quickly launched widespread testing and have some of the highest per-capita testing rates in the world. Their ability to identify and isolate those infected has helped prevent deadlier outcomes.

question: Why can’t we just test everyone in the US? If we isolate all the asymptomatic carriers, couldn’t the rest of us go back to work?
answer:
Doctors say it’s not realistic to test all 328 million people in the US, especially since many states are still struggling to get enough tests or testing supplies.
So in order for the economy to reopen and stay open, the US will need to triple its number of tests performed every day — from 150,000 tests a day to at least 500,000, three Harvard researchers found.
And the proportion of test results that come back positive needs to be much lower. About 20% of US test results have been positive, which is “clearly way too high,” said Dr. Thomas Tsai, one of the Harvard researchers. 
The World Health Organization said an adequate range of positive test results would be 3% to 12%. Germany and South Korea have already met that goal, Tsai said.

question: Can coronavirus stick to clothes? Do I need to wash my clothes right after encountering other people, like at the grocery store or while jogging?
answer:
“I don’t think you need to,” CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. 
Coronavirus can stay alive for up to three days on stainless steel and plastic. But clothing “is probably more like cardboard — it’s more absorbent, so the virus is unlikely to stay and last that long,” Gupta said. 
While covonravirus can stay alive on cardboard for up to 24 hours, viruses generally don’t stick well on surfaces that are in motion. 
“If you look at how viruses move through air, they kind of want to move around objects,” Gupta said. “They don’t want to necessarily land on objects. So if you’re moving as human body through the air … (it’s) unlikely to stick to your clothes.”

question: Can coronavirus spread through water, like in a swimming pool or hot tub?
answer:
“There is no evidence that COVID-19 can be spread to humans through the use of pools and hot tubs,” the CDC says. 
“Proper operation, maintenance, and disinfection (e.g., with chlorine and bromine) of pools and hot tubs should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.”
But health officials still advise staying at least 6 feet away from others because COVID-19 is a respiratory disease. In other words, you probably won’t get coronavirus from the water, but you could get coronavirus from someone close to you in the water. 
As for drinking water, doctors say you don’t need to worry about coronavirus in the tap water because most municipal drinking water systems should remove or inactivate the virus.

question: How can someone spread coronavirus when asymptomatic? If they’re not sneezing or coughing, how can they infect others?
answer:
It’s easy for asymptomatic people to spread coronavirus, said Dr. Anne Rimoin, an epidemiology professor at UCLA’s School of Public Health.
“When you speak, sometimes you’ll spit a little bit,” she said. “You’ll rub your nose. You’ll touch your mouth. You’ll rub your eyes. And then you’ll touch other surfaces, and then you will be spreading virus if you are infected and shedding asymptomatically.”

question: Will an antibody test show whether I’m immune and can go back to work?
answer:
Not necessarily. Antibodies are a body’s response to bacteria or viruses. But this novel coronavirus is so new, it’s still not clear whether having antibodies to it means you have long-term protection from getting reinfected. 
“The thing we don’t know yet is what is the relationship between the level of antibody and the degree of your protection,” Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told Snapchat’s “Good Luck America” show. 
“So you may be positive for an antibody, but not enough to protect you.” 
There’s also a risk that some antibody tests might confuse the novel coronavirus with other coronaviruses, like the ones that cause the common cold.

question: If novel coronavirus antibodies may or may not offer long-term immunity, how would a vaccine help?
answer:
In some cases, a vaccine might give stronger protection than antibodies produced after being infected, epidemiologist Dr. Larry Brilliant said. 
“There are actually six other coronavirus – MERS and SARS and four other viruses that create the common cold. They don’t seem to do very well at creating long-term immunity,” Brilliant said. 
“But we need to find out whether we can create a vaccine that creates more immunity [to the novel coronavirus] than the disease does. And that’s not so wild. Many of the vaccines that we’ve made in history are actually stronger than the virus is itself at creating immunity.”

question: Are some blood types able to fight this coronavirus better than other blood types?
answer:
“With this respiratory virus, (as) with other coronaviruses, no,” said Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove, technical lead for the World Health Organization’s Covid-19 response.
“All of us are susceptible to this virus,” she said. “It’s a new virus, which means we haven’t had a chance to build immunity.”

question: Can I use vodka as hand sanitizer?
answer:
Please don’t. The CDC advises using hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.
Vodka typically contains between 35% and 46% percent alcohol.
If the stores are out of hand sanitizer and you want to make your own, the Nebraska Medical Center offers this recipe:
What you’ll need:

2/3 cup 91% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol)
1/3 cup aloe vera gel
Mixing bowl
Spoon or something for whisking
Small container, such as a 3-oz. travel bottle
Optional: essential oil to give your hand sanitizer a fragrance

Directions:In a mixing bowl, stir isopropyl alcohol and aloe vera gel together until well blended.Add 8-10 drops of scented essential oil (optional, but nice). Stir.Pour the homemade hand sanitizer into an empty container and seal. Write “hand sanitizer” on a piece of masking tape and attach to the bottle.

question: Are smokers or vapers at higher risk? What if I only smoke weed?
answer:
This is not a good time to be vaping or smoking anything, including weed. 
“Vaping affects your lungs at every level. It affects the immune function in your nasal cavity by affecting cilia, which push foreign things out,” said Prof. Stanton Glantz, director of the Center for Tobacco Research Control and Education at University of California San Francisco.
When you vape, “the ability of your upper airways to clear viruses is compromised,” Glantz said.
Tobacco smokers are at especially high risk. In a study from China, where the first Covid-19 outbreak occurred, smokers were 14 times more likely to develop severe complications than non-smokers.
Even occasionally smoking marijuana can put you at greater risk.
“What happens to your airways when you smoke cannabis is that it causes some degree of inflammation, very similar to bronchitis, very similar to the type of inflammation that cigarette smoking can cause,” said pulmonologist Dr. Albert Rizzo, chief medical officer for the American Lung Association.
“Now you have some airway inflammation, and you get an infection on top of it. So yes, your chance of getting more complications is there.”

question: Can I get coronavirus through food? Is it safe to eat takeout from restaurants?
answer:
There’s no evidence that coronavirus can be transmitted through food, the CDC says. 
Even if coronavirus does get into your food, your stomach acid would kill it, said Dr. Angela Rasmussen, a virologist at Columbia University.
“When you eat any kind of food, whether it be hot or cold, that food is going to go straight down into your stomach, where there’s a high acidity, low-pH environment that will inactivate the virus,” she said.
But it’s a good idea to disinfect the takeout containers, CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. Coronavirus is a respiratory virus, and it’s easy to touch your face without realizing it.
If you don’t have disinfecting wipes, use your own plates or bowls to serve the food. Just make sure to wash your hands after transferring food from the containers.

question: My teenagers aren’t taking this seriously. Any advice?
answer:
Coronavirus isn’t just infecting young people. It’s killing young, healthy people as well. 
We’ve reported many stories about young people getting severely sick with or dying from coronavirus.
Dimitri Mitchell, 18, admits he had a “false sense of security.” But he was later hospitalized with coronavirus and now wants everyone to take it seriously. 
“I just want to make sure everybody knows that no matter what their age is, it can seriously affect them. And it can seriously mess them up, like it messed me up,” the Iowa teen said. 
He started feeling sick on St. Patrick’s Day, with just a small cough. “I thought at first it was just a normal cold. And then it started progressively getting worse,” he said. 
“Four days in, the really bad symptoms started coming along. I started having really bad outbreaks, like sweating, and my eyes were really watery. I was getting warmer and warmer, and I was super fatigued. … I would start experiencing the worst headaches I’ve ever felt in my life. They were absolutely horrible.”
Eventually, the teen had to be hospitalized. His mother said she worried he might “fall asleep and never wake up.” 
Mitchell is now recovering, but still has a cough almost a month later. 
“I just hope everybody’s responsible, because it’s nothing to joke about,” he said. “It’s a real problem, and I want everybody to make sure they’re following social distancing guidelines and the group limits. And just listen to all the rules and precautions and stay up to date with the news and make sure they’re informed.”

question: Does this pandemic have anything to do with the 5G network?
answer:
No. That’s just a hoax going around the internet.
“The theory that 5G might compromise the immune system and thus enable people to get sick from corona is based on nothing,” said Eric van Rongen, chairman of the International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection (ICNIRP). 
Learn more about how 5G really works and why this hoax makes no sense.

question: My ex and I have joint custody of our kids. Is it safe for them to go between two homes?
answer:
Ideally, you should limit your children’s potential exposures to coronavirus and work out the safest plan possible with your ex. 
The problem: Most state and county family courts are closed, or open only for emergencies involving abuse or endangerment. So if parents wanted to formally modify pre-existing custody agreements, they can’t.
But some states may be offering some flexibility during the pandemic. And there may be creative solutions, such as spending more time with one parent now in exchange for extra time with the other parent after the pandemic ends.

question: How long does coronavirus stay “alive” on surfaces?
answer:
Up to three days, depending on the surface. According to a study funded by the US National Institutes of Health:

The novel coronavirus is viable up to 72 hours after being placed on stainless steel and plastic.
It was viable up to four hours after being placed on copper, and up to 24 hours after being put on cardboard.
In aerosols, it was viable for three hours.

question: Will a pneumonia or flu vaccine help protect against coronavirus?
answer:
Some cases of coronavirus do lead to pneumonia. But the pneumonia vaccine won’t help.
“Vaccines against pneumonia, such as pneumococcal vaccine and Haemophilus influenza type B (Hib) vaccine, only help protect people from these specific bacterial infections,” according to Harvard Medical School.
“They do not protect against any coronavirus pneumonia.”
The flu shot does not protect against coronavirus. But it does help protect against a massive, unnecessary burden on hospitals already overwhelmed with coronavirus.
The CDC estimates about 140,000 to 810,000 people are hospitalized with the flu every year in the US. And about half of Americans don’t get vaccinated – including most children who die from the flu.

question: Should I wear a face mask in public? If so, how do I make one?
answer:
The CDC recently changed its guidance on wearing face masks as more studies about asymptomatic spread pile up.
Now, the CDC “recommends wearing cloth face coverings in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain (e.g., grocery stores and pharmacies).”
But there are several important caveats and key points: 

The public should NOT buy surgical masks or N95 respirator masks. Those are desperately needed by health care workers who are in close contact with coronavirus patients every day. 
Instead, make your own cloth mask — it’s easy, and you don’t have to sew. US Surgeon General Jerome Adams shows how to make face masks with just a T-shirt and rubber bands in this CDC video. You can also use a bandana and a coffee filter. 
Don’t be fooled: The main benefit of wearing masks in public isn’t to protect you from getting sick. Rather, it’s to protect others from yourself if you’re sick or you’re an asymptomatic carrier. “This is more for people who might be infected and don’t know it, and to try and lower the likelihood that they will spread this to somebody else,” CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. The CDC agreed.
You can definitely still get coronavirus even if you wear a mask. The virus can stay alive on surfaces for up to 3 days, and it’s easy to touch your face whenever you’re not wearing a mask. Also, people often adjust face masks frequently, leading to more touching of the face — a common way that coronavirus spreads.
It’s important to wash your cloth mask after every use. Here’s how. 
Wearing cloth masks is just “an additional, voluntary public health measure,” the CDC said. To protect yourself from getting coronavirus, it’s critical to stay 6 feet away from others, wash your hands frequently for at least 20 seconds each time, and stop touching your face.

question: How long will we have to keep social distancing?
answer:
Probably for several months. But you might have to do it “over and over again,” since the outbreak could come in waves.
Research by the Imperial College in Great Britain “would suggest you have to institute these kinds of measures for five months, very vigorously,” said Dr. Celine Gounder, an infectious disease specialist at Bellevue Hospital Center. 
“And then you may be able to relax for a period. And then you would re-institute as the cases go up again. But we’re basically looking at doing this over and over and over again, even after a five-month period of strict social distancing, in order to curb cases until we have a vaccine.”
Health officials say we’re at least a year away from the first publicly available coronavirus vaccine.

question: Why is a cure taking so long?
answer:
An antiviral drug must be able to target the specific part of a virus’s life cycle that is necessary for it to reproduce, according to Harvard Medical School.
“In addition, an antiviral drug must be able to kill a virus without killing the human cell it occupies. And viruses are highly adaptive.”

question: Why are medical workers getting sick with or dying from coronavirus if they’re wearing protective gear? Does the viral load matter?
answer:
Many health care workers don’t actually have enough protective gear to handle the growing influx of coronavirus patients. 
Some have resorted to using plastic report covers as masks. The CDC said medical providers might have to use expired masks or reuse them between multiple patients. (This shortage is why the general public should not buy medical masks and instead make cloth masks at home.)
But it’s not just subpar protective gear that puts medical workers at risk. It’s also the amount of virus they’re exposed to. 
“The viral load — the amount of virus – does determine the severity of your illness,” emergency room physician Dr. Leana Wen said. “So that could happen in the case of health care workers who are exposed to a lot more Covid-19 as a result of their work — that they get more severely ill.”

question: We’ve been sheltering in place for weeks. So why are the “peaks” of hospitalizations and deaths still yet to come in some places?
answer:
“There is a delay because the way it goes, you have people who get exposed; they get infected; the number of new infections, hospitalizations, critical care and deaths (follow),” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. 
“So even when you suppress or stabilize the number of new infections, it’s still going to take a while before you see a decrease in hospitalizations, a decrease in intensive care, and a decrease in deaths. And in fact, deaths are the last thing that lag. So you could be doing well (with mitigation measures) and still see the deaths go up.”

question: Can I have the flu and coronavirus at the same time?
answer:
Yes. Testing positive for either the flu or coronavirus doesn’t exempt you from having the other at the same time. 
The flu and coronavirus share some common symptoms, such as fever and cough.
But many coronavirus patients suffer from shortness of breath, and some people with coronavirus lose their senses of taste or smell. But it’s important to note many people with coronavirus — possibly up to 50% — have no symptoms at all.
Learn more about the differences between flu, coronavirus and allergy symptoms here.

question: How many people with coronavirus don't have symptoms? Are they still contagious?
answer:
In one study, about 4 in 5 people with confirmed coronavirus in China were likely infected by people who didn’t know they had it, according to research published in the journal “Science.”
“These findings explain the rapid geographic spread of (coronavirus) and indicate containment of this virus will be particularly challenging,” researchers wrote.
In mid-March, the CDC said almost half of the 712 people with coronavirus who were on the Diamond Princess cruise ship didn’t have any symptoms when they tested positive.
And recent studies suggest 25% to 50% of coronavirus carriers don’t have symptoms.
In the US, “I think it could be as many as 1 in 3 walking around asymptomatic,” said New Jersey primary care physician Dr. Alex Salerno.
“We have tested some patients that have known exposure to COVID (coronavirus disease). They did not have temperature. Their pulse/(oxygen) was OK.”
Aside from social distancing and frequent hand washing, Salerno said more testing of people without symptoms is essential.
When asymptomatic carriers test positive, “we isolate them, and we separate them from the people who are not positive,” Salerno said. If more asymptomatic people got tested, “we could get people back to work safely.”
But there haven’t been nearly enough tests in the US for everyone who wants one, due to shortages, delays and faulty test kits.

question: If there’s no cure, why go to the hospital unless you have a breathing problem?
answer:
Most coronavirus patients don’t need to be hospitalized. “The vast majority of people – about 80% – will do well without any specific intervention,” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
Those patients should get plenty of rest, hydrate frequently and take fever-reducing medication.
“The current guidance – and this may change – is that if you have symptoms that are similar to the cold and the flu and these are mild symptoms to moderate symptoms, stay at home and try to manage them,” said Dr. Patrice Harris, president of the American Medical Association. 
But about 20% of coronavirus patients get advanced disease. “Older patients and individuals who have underlying medical conditions or are immunocompromised should contact their physician early in the course of even mild illness,” the CDC says.
The CDC also says you should get immediate help if you have: 

Trouble breathing
Persistent pain or pressure in the chest
